content:
Hmmm, very interesting. I wonder if a fast-converging series for pi would work or not. Maybe 1,000,000 digits is too big for that. If there's a nice formula for partial sum of such series then maybe we can truncate the calculation and go straight to whatever digit we want. But of course, if said series involves irrational terms then this idea can go straight to a garbage can.

On second thought, this probably won't work. : (

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle
After the 295k digit and the 1M digit versions of the puzzle get approved, I will be looking forward to the "Chuck Norris" edition, in which you need to print ALL digits of Pi... ;-)
Keep it up

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reasoning:
Clear Problem Statement:

Objective: Participants are tasked with outputting the requested digits of Pi, which is specific and well-defined.
Input and Output: The input (INDEX and N) and expected output are clearly described with examples illustrating the required behavior.
Appropriate Constraints:

INDEX < 1,000,000: Ensures calculations remain within a manageable range.
N â‰¤ 50: Limits the number of digits to a reasonable amount, even for high INDEX values.
Difficulty Level:

"Very Hard": Suitable for advanced programmers, involving optimization and advanced algorithms like the Chudnovsky algorithm.
Algorithm Hint: The ROT13 hint subtly points towards an efficient method without giving away the solution.
Comprehensive Test Cases:

Various scenarios, including high INDEX values and maximum N, ensure solutions are both efficient and correct.
Provided Solution:

The Bash solution using GMP (GNU Multiple Precision Arithmetic Library) offers a solid reference for handling large numbers, aiding participants in understanding possible approaches.
Educational Value:

Participants learn to manage large numbers and implement precise calculations, as well as apply advanced algorithms for efficiency.
Optimization Focus:

Encourages thinking about algorithmic efficiency and resource management, which are critical programming skills.


Recommendations:
Additional Resources: Providing more information or resources on the Chudnovsky algorithm could help participants better understand and implement efficient solutions.
Input Validation: Ensure inputs adhere to the constraints to prevent unexpected behavior.
that's nice puzzle

âŒ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I think that the best way to solve this puzzle is :
- google "best algorithm to get million digits of pi"
- copy/paste the algorithm.
There is no place for any personal coding

I stumbled across the Baileyâ€“Borweinâ€“Plouffe formula, which can apparently compute later digits of pi without computing all the preceding digits. That's really cool, I had no idea. However, the formulas provided only work in base 16. There's apparently a way to get these in base 10 as well, but the cited 2022 article that claims as much doesn't give an explicit algorithm, it just kind of expresses the existence of one indirectly. If it's possible to do a second way then I like the problem a lot more.

It was very interesting to read about how pi can be effectively calculated (following the rot13 hint). I don't agree with the comments that this would not be a great puzzle.

Out of curiousity I tried to solve it in PHP. Local run of test #02 (79k digits) took over 1100sec... I used the standard bcmath library which is rather slow, and each arithmethic operation involves copying the inefficient string representation of the number... I am not sure if the GMP facade would be faster, CG does not provide the gmp library for PHP.

I also wanted to try it out in Rust but realized that CG does not provide any arbitrary precision crate for Rust. I made it work locally with num-bigint crate, but I might miss something because it takes 51 sec (but it spends 98% of this in a single sqrt call)

I cannot approve on CG as I have no working solution on CG platfrom, only local ones.

Is there a way to not compute the first decimal and only the range to show ?
If not, i think i can't pass it with javascript / typescript

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice puzzle, as i will agree with the coder who asked for hint ;)
Looks like an interesting project, especially since the algorithm evoked doesn't seem to need additional libraries beyond the standard ones

I know you a few years ago by the way nice puzzle.

Guess who i am.

I found this interesting. I did some research and have an idea on a solution, however to achieve the speed needed I need access to some heavier libraries for doing "arbitrary precision arithmetic". I see that your also use the gmp library for c++, but use bash for referencing it, as it will not work with c++.

Maybe I am not qualified for this, so my question is, can the problem be solved without using this library, and is that the point of it?

I tried solving it in Python, however mpmath and gmpy2 are not avail.
i finally solved this in ruby. it was quite fun!
Will approve after trying out some methods (:
A fresh set of approvals for the greatest problem ever posed!

âŒ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The first two approvals were from 3 years ago, and they're from the same person (their profile descriptions are the same). This contribution should be subject to fresh reviews instead of being approved too soon (within 24 hours) after re-publication.

Math puzzles are very popular lately (BÃ©zier curves, Derivative time pt 1&2, Random time travel, N Perls Necklace, etc.).  So the time seems right for this one to be approved.

It works up to 11 million in c++, keeping it to 1M for slower languages.

In my opinion what is fun is using your brain to solve problems and then use your programming skills to implement the solution.
Most of us don't know how to compute the decimals of PI because it is useless in life. In software we are using an already implemented function and in real life, we use 3 or 3.14 depending on what we need PI for.
So to solve this puzzle we will need to google it, and then it will just be a matter of implementing the found formula, which will probably be very easy.
For this problem you have just to make an array of all the first 1million digit of pi with one Ctrl+C Ctrl+V in Google and output the good index of the array..... Not really interesting

You could use ramunujan's formula for this
Or even better use Chudonovosky's formula which is an improvement of ramunujan's formula/series

The problem should be categorised as VERY VERY HARD. This should not belong to any coding platform rather it is a good research topic. However would you please explain the solution in detail? I see some magic number and crazy things going in the solution. Interested to know the details.
Interested in ! A human is able to do it "only" for the first tens of thousands digits!
This problem seems too easy with Google but too hard without Google
One of the problems easyly solvable with google but intresting without
Cool problem but feels a bit easy. Let me solve it
it is better but difficulty level should be medium

More a "project euler" problem than a CG puzzle in my opinion.

As other say, Nintendo puzzle is a special case (sponsored puzzle, specific recruitment need ...) not very representative of a typical CG puzzle.

And the algorithm behind Nintendo puzzle has concrete applications, even if I admit that pointing the usefullness or not of certain mathematics things can be seen as trolling ^^. Perhaps they discover in the future a shocking use of the billions of computed digits of pi (other that a "random" numbers mine).

Finally the educational interest of this puzzle is very weak, in my opinion. I have few interest  in massive computation problem, I'm more interested by algorithms and usage of those algorithms, and I think I'm not alone in this feeling.
I feel that it's a bit too easy to cheese with the first 1,000,000 million digits of pi. Can't you just copy and paste it into a string and then parse the string?

If the posted solution wasn't obfuscated I think it would be easier for someone to verify that it is indeed doable in the 1sec processing time limit and that the solution is general. (Updated: it does, see conversation)

I tend to agree with the others.
1. No, the Nintendo puzzle is not just an obscure math algorithm. It's also significantly obfuscated behind bit calculations.
2. The Nintendo puzzle is the only one I've encountered here like that that didn't at least have a story or some sort of catch. In fact, it has a story.
3. Although this can be solved with internet searches, it's not interesting at all. It's just not that engaging. IMO, this site is far more interesting than any random collection of programming puzzles in some app made in India because it has Indiana Jones, Captain Kirk, Batman, etc. Regardless of easy or hard, this problem doesn't strike me as much better than on SoloLearn or a thousand other site/apps. Subjectively, of course!
You need to leave some clue on how to do this, I searched on google, and I didn't find an algorithm that can deliver me what you ask for in the time limit. Hardcoding should not be a solution.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Do Nice Job Westicles

âŒ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: There is not even a clue about the real difficulty of the problem.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is best he used a lot of time to do this
Interesting Problem... But it feels difficulty.

âŒ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: One of those math tasks, where you have to google how to do it, unless you belong to 0.1% who happen to know it. And once you google it, you basically copy the algorithm. Further, the shown solution is obfuscated for no reason. I think it is a good challenge, but not a programming one, so it doesn't belong here.
It would be great to add some link to how it can be calculated.
I think it should be noted as difficult
That's a little strange... here's a puzzle for you, and let me spoil it right away by linking an answer.

I disagree.  The Nintendo Sponsored Contest is at the apex of the problems on this site, and it certainly involves figuring out arcane math that few people know.  This one involves researching the fastest available algorithms for a well-known task, which is certainly fair game around here.
And?

Also it may not seem fair, but the Nintendo puzzle is sponsored by a huge company that is interested in those who solve it. That, like it or not, makes it more interesting.
If this contribution gets approved, why not just copy all the exercises from a programming book onto CodinGame?
Well, okay but I'm not sure how the solution is obfuscated. Is it not clear from the cout line that you could change the two input parameters to any other position to spot check?

No, you are limited to 100k characters.  I tried this approach on a previous version of this puzzle, the best I could do was 295k: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5711ae76355cbe214cc9d89823c14e69d855

Thanks. It is hard due to the complexity involved in programming the solution. The wiki however does not say anything about your proposed solution.

Is your solution based on "Binary splitting of the arctan series in Machin's formula (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Machin)"?

ðŸ˜‚ You have a limit of 100k chars for your code in CG IDE. So you can start to first compress your million of digits, copy paste the compressed version in CG IDE and decompress it in your code before using it...a little bit more complex than ctrl-c ctrl-v.

Individual taste is a thing.  Some people like figuring out this kind of stuff, some don't.  But I will say, the solution definitely isn't easy.  I doubt more than 3-4 people on this site could put together a working solution.
You are right.  God bless the spirited Indian lad who approved this twice long ago.
You decided not to approve after all?

Hi, using gmp was just a shortcut, it should be easy enough to port in your favorite big number functions.  GMP timed out at around 13 million digits if I recall, so I limited it to 1M to make it easier.

And looks like NicknamedTwice solved it in Ruby (but didn't approve it... not sure if he has other concerns).
but have u solved it? and if yes, then which language?

Yes, it looks like the solution is using modular arithmetic somehow. Otherwise, a direct implementation of Chudnovsky, adopted from the Wikipedia article for instance, is going to time out long before getting anywhere near the limit.

It's super funny that "Chudnovsky Algorithm" is encrypted in ROT13, as if anyone could possibly solve this without knowing about that. Yeah, maybe they can reinvent it from scratch, sure!

Actually  there is already an approved puzzle on CG to utilize this formula:
https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/baileyborweinplouffe-pi
Maybe you should stick to easy puzzles?  It seems you don't know what you are talking about.  Perhaps you can explore the Dunning-Kruger effect.
bro did not need to write allat ðŸ˜­
fr
Oh, man, I tried to solve it three different ways, but successed nothing. So it's not as easy as you thought.
Your pathetic views have been rejected by better men.

It looks like that puzzle tests up to the 100,000th digit, and only a single digit at a time. It's an older algorithm, and I suspect it must be slower, given that this is the one used to break records.

I'm not a math guy, there might be a bunch of ways to solve it.  I'm kind of surprised how upset people get at the idea of finding the best algorithm on their own.  I thought researching different approaches would be fun, but that seems to be a rare skill here.

What does it mean to solve something on your own? There has to be a starting point somewhere, otherwise in the description you'd have to define what's meant by pi. I suppose a person could start with the formula by Ramanujan (who had what's considered possibly the greatest mathematical mind ever), because there were a lot of brilliant people before that (Fibonacci, Newton, Leibniz, and Euler are just a few of many who have tackled this over the centuries) whose knowledge of pi would have been insufficient to solve this puzzle. And even starting with Ramanujan, if led to do that, they'd still have to have an insight on par with what the Chudnovsky brothers did. So yes, it's a rare skill, but not just here.
You don't see the difference between implementing an algorithm you are told to implement, vs. looking at all the algorithms in the literature and choosing the best one?

That's fair. I had a hint in one of my puzzles to use the Alias method, and it was really disappointing to see solutions that were direct copies of an available implementation, down to the variable names.

"Yes, it looks like the solution is using modular arithmetic somehow."
Maybe I misunderstand the example code, but I don't see any modular arithmetics there. It modified the original C. formula just to avoid having to use arbitrary precision float in the sqrt() part. It is just arbitrary precision integer sqrt(), although with 2 million digits...
What I don't understand in the example code is where the 70518 is coming from. Why is this the upper limit for the binary split for the C formula to be valid for 1m digits?
Oh, thanks for the correction.
python

Thanks for the clarification.

I will try to solve it without the shortcut.

I will let others approve this, I am out of my league here :)

Best wishes

I made it work without GMP in Python, but never got nowhere near the speed I needed, think I could do only 20K digits even with binary split it took 46 secs.

I had fun though. 

I would love to see a solution without GMP in any language, I tried soo many things, even different languages.
yea sorry i didn't approve it earlier. it was bugging out before
no, sorry. i felt that its too hard for most people on this website and not worth adding it here. maybe a different website, like codewars or something else, would be a better choice for this puzzle
Hey, if you don't mind publishing your Ruby solution, I'd love to see what it looks like.

import zlib
zlib.decompress(data)
I tried. 1 million digits cannot be easily compressed into 100k, as the digits are random.Where am I wrong?
Ok but this problem if anyone wants to solve would do by googling ans copy pasting solution. I don't see any fun in this. Hence it cannot be approved.
Oh I see, now that I hand-fed you the solution it isn't any fun.  Give me a break.
But can't you use an array of strings where all strings contain 100k digits ?
Give it a try!

Hot take: Maybe compressing a group of 50-75 digits into a product of smaller primes and then putting them back into strings would be slightly better, but of course, that would be too much work (would be impressive if someone does that though)
After looking you up, it's obvious you've got the chops to code this.  I'll update the original post to be more constructive

Good point.  I see in the code that the entire sequence is calculated,  so yes you are correct this is easy to verify.  Also, I did some reading and read through the code it I believe I know which formula you are using.  Neat!

I was shocked that such a thing is possible in 1 sec.  I probably agree with others that it isn't a good problem for this site since it isn't 'fun' and there is no way you could solve it in Clojure or whatever, but it is still amazing. :)
I appreciate your opinion :)
I believe, these are the programming challenges, not math tasks.
Choosing which of the many available algorithms to use is part of the programming challenge.
